{{short description|English association football player}} {{other people}} {{pp|small=yes}} {{EngvarB|date=December 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2018}} {{Good article}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Harry Kane | image = Harry Kane in Russia 2.jpg | image_size = 200 | caption = Kane training with [[England national football team|England]] at the [[2018 FIFA World Cup]] | fullname = Harry Edward Kane<ref name=Hugman>{{Hugman|23634|accessdate=31 March 2016}}</ref> | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1993|7|28|df=y}}<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.11v11.com/players/harry-kane-230567/ |title=Harry Kane |website=11v11.com |publisher=AFS Enterprises |accessdate=6 December 2017}}</ref> | birth_place = [[Walthamstow]], England | height = {{convert|1.88|m|order=flip}}<ref name=Profile>{{cite web |url=https://www.premierleague.com/players/3960/Harry-Kane/overview |title=Harry Kane: Overview |publisher=Premier League |accessdate=13 December 2017}}</ref> | position = [[Forward (association football)#Striker|Striker]] | currentclub = [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] | clubnumber = 10 | youthyears1 = 1999–2001 | youthclubs1 = Ridgeway Rovers | youthyears2 = 2001–2002 | youthclubs2 = [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] | youthyears3 = 2002–2004 | youthclubs3 = Ridgeway Rovers | youthyears4 = 2004 | youthclubs4 = [[Watford F.C.|Watford]] | youthyears5 = 2004–2009 | youthclubs5 = [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C. Reserves and Academy|Tottenham Hotspur]] | years1 = 2009– | clubs1 = [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] | caps1 = 174 | goals1 = 124 | years2 = 2011 | clubs2 = → [[Leyton Orient F.C.|Leyton Orient]] (loan) | caps2 = 18 | goals2 = 5 | years3 = 2012 | clubs3 = → [[Millwall F.C.|Millwall]] (loan) | caps3 = 22 | goals3 = 7 | years4 = 2012–2013 | clubs4 = → [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]] (loan) | caps4 = 3 | goals4 = 0 | years5 = 2013 | clubs5 = → [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] (loan) | caps5 = 13 | goals5 = 2 | nationalyears1 = 2010 | nationalteam1 = [[England national under-17 football team|England U17]] | nationalcaps1 = 3 | nationalgoals1 = 2 | nationalyears2 = 2010–2012 | nationalteam2 = [[England national under-19 football team|England U19]] | nationalcaps2 = 14 | nationalgoals2 = 6 | nationalyears3 = 2013 | nationalteam3 = [[England national under-20 football team|England U20]] | nationalcaps3 = 3 | nationalgoals3 = 1 | nationalyears4 = 2013–2015 | nationalteam4 = [[England national under-21 football team|England U21]] | nationalcaps4 = 14 | nationalgoals4 = 8 | nationalyears5 = 2015– | nationalteam5 = [[England national football team|England]] | nationalcaps5 = 35 | nationalgoals5 = 20 | club-update = 15:58, 2 March 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = 15:22, 12 January 2019 (UTC) }} '''Harry Edward Kane''' {{post-nominals|country=GBR|MBE}} (born 28 July 1993) is an English professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Forward (association football)#Striker|striker]] for {{English football updater|TottenhH}} club [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] and [[Captain (association football)|captains]] the [[England national football team|England national team]]. Many panel members commissioned by ''[[The Guardian]]'' considered him to be one of the best players in the world in 2018.{{efn|A voting panel comprised 225 judges (coaches, broadcasters, reporters, correspondents, editors, and former players) from 69 countries (19 judges from Africa, 20 from Asia, 140 from Europe, 11 from North and Central America, and 35 from South America).}}<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/ng-interactive/2018/dec/18/the-100-best-male-footballers-in-the-world-2018-nos-100-71 |title=The 100 best male footballers in the world 2018 |website=[[TheGuardian.com]] |date=20 December 2018 |accessdate=13 January 2019}}</ref>
Born and raised in [[Walthamstow]], Kane began his professional career at Tottenham Hotspur, where, after fast progression through the team's youth academy, he was promoted to the senior team in 2009, at age 16. He did not initially feature for the side, and instead, was [[Loan (sports)|loan]]ed out several times to clubs across the [[English football league system|English football pyramid]], including [[Leyton Orient F.C.|Leyton Orient]], [[Millwall F.C.|Millwall]], [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]], and [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]].
Kane's involvement at Tottenham began to increase following the appointment of [[Mauricio Pochettino]] as head coach in 2014. In his [[2014–15 Tottenham Hotspur F.C. season|first full season]] at the club, Kane netted 31 goals across all competitions, and finished as the league's second highest goalscorer, winning the [[PFA Young Player of the Year]] award. After the [[2015–16 Premier League|following campaign]], at age 23, Kane finished as league's [[List of top Premier League goal scorers by season#2015.E2.80.9316|top goalscorer]], and guided the club to [[UEFA Champions League]] qualification. In the [[2016–17 Premier League|2016–17 season]], Kane also completed the season as the league's top goalscorer, and helped the club finish as the competition's runners-up, while he won the [[PFA Fans' Player of the Year]] award. In the [[2017–18 Tottenham Hotspur F.C. season|2017–18 season]], Kane registered his best campaign statistically to date, with 41 goals scored in 48 games in all competitions.
Kane holds the record for most [[Premier League Player of the Month]] awards (six; shared with [[Steven Gerrard]]) and has been selected for the [[PFA Team of the Year]] four times. He established himself as Tottenham's fourth [[List of Tottenham Hotspur F.C. records and statistics#Top 10 all-time scorers|all-time scorer]] in official competitions in January 2019, and holds the [[List of Premier League players with 100 or more goals|best strike-rate]] (0.70 goals per game) in Premier League history.
An English international, Kane has scored 20 goals in 35 games for his country. He has appeared and scored at every youth level, and made his senior debut in March 2015 at age 22, where he scored on his debut. Kane featured and scored at [[UEFA Euro 2016 qualifying]], before he was selected as the squad's captain from May 2018, prior to the [[2018 FIFA World Cup]]. In the tournament, Kane led England to fourth-place, their highest finish since 1990, by finishing as the top goalscorer, and won the [[FIFA World Cup awards|Golden Boot]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/44840817 |title=World Cup 2018: Harry Kane wins Golden Boot |publisher=BBC Sport |date=15 July 2018 |accessdate=15 July 2018}}</ref>
==Early life== Harry Edward Kane was born in [[Walthamstow]], London to Kim and Patrick Kane and has one older brother, Charlie.<ref name=tottenhamhotspur>{{cite web |url=http://www.tottenhamhotspur.com/first-team-squad/harry-kane/ |title=Harry Kane |publisher=Tottenham Hotspur F.C.}}</ref><ref name=jim/><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.standard.co.uk/news/london/one-day-ill-play-for-england-london-schoolboys-dream-is-about-to-come-true-10138435.html |title=One day I'll play for England: London schoolboy's dream is about to come true |first=John |last=Dunne |newspaper=London Evening Standard |date=27 March 2015 |accessdate=2 February 2018}}</ref> He has Irish ancestry through his father who is from [[Galway]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.irishpost.com/sport/5-things-never-knew-harry-kanes-surprising-irish-roots-156293 |title=5 things you never knew about Harry Kane's surprising Irish roots |last=Beresford |first=Jack |newspaper=The Irish Post |accessdate=26 June 2018}}</ref><ref name="galway">{{cite news |url=http://www.the42.ie/harry-kane-england-2001121-Mar2015/ |publisher=The 42 |title=Let's forget about Harry Kane for Ireland, he's after getting an England call-up |date=28 March 2015}}</ref> The family moved to [[Chingford]] where he attended Larkswood Primary Academy until 2004,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.guardian-series.co.uk/news/13424088.New_sporting_talent_unearthed_at_Harry_Kane_s_primary_school/ |title=New sporting talent unearthed at Harry Kane's primary school |first=Natalie |last=Glanvill |newspaper=East London and West Sussex Guardian |date=16 July 2015 |accessdate=2 February 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://larkswoodlime.london/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/NEWSLETTER-WB-16th-Feb-2015.pdf |title=Larkswood Primary Academy Newsletter |date=9 February 2015 |access-date=1 October 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171002022012/http://larkswoodlime.london/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/NEWSLETTER-WB-16th-Feb-2015.pdf |archive-date=2 October 2017 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> followed by [[Chingford Foundation School]] (also attended by [[David Beckham]]).<ref>{{cite web |title=Hall of Fame |url=https://chingfordpedept.wordpress.com/hall-of-fame |website=Chingford Foundation School PE Department |accessdate=3 May 2017}}</ref> He played football from a young age, joining a local club, Ridgeway Rovers, when he was six in 1999.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/44625669 |title=World Cup 2018: Harry Kane – the making of England & Tottenham striker |date=2 July 2018 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=9 July 2018}}</ref> Kane talked about footballing in the family:
{{cquote|I think the sporting genes come from my Mum's side of the family although the topic is a hot debate in the Kane household. Dad probably won't like me saying that, but I think my granddad Eric on my Mum's side was quite a good footballer, and played at a decent level.<ref name="worrall 2">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VH2pDgAAQBAJ&pg=PT7&lpg=PT7#v=onepage |title=Harry Kane – The Biography |first=Frank |last=Worrall |isbn=9781786065384 |chapter=Chapter 1: Beginnings |publisher=John Blake Publishing Ltd |date=18 May 2017}}</ref>}}
Kane also said: "Most of my family were Spurs fans and I grew up 15 minutes from the ground, so I was always going to be a Spurs fan".<ref name="worrall 2"/> He named former Spurs striker [[Teddy Sheringham]] his childhood idol, and saw him as a "great finisher" and a role model in his ability to get in the [[penalty area|box]] and score goals.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/harry-kane-teddy-sheringham-has-been-a-great-role-model-for-me-9285534.html |title=Harry Kane: Teddy Sheringham has been a great role model for me |first=Simon |last=Peach |newspaper=The Independent |location=London |date=25 April 2014 |accessdate=2 February 2018}}</ref> Other childhood sporting influences he cited include David Beckham and [[Jermain Defoe]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.hitc.com/en-gb/2015/05/20/kanes-childhood-heroes-consisted-of-sheringham-beckham-and-d/ |title=Tottenham striker Harry Kane's childhood heroes consisted of Sheringham, Beckham and Defoe |first=Dale |last=O'Donnell |website=HITC |date=20 May 2015 |accessdate=25 November 2018}}</ref> Kane has also spoken of his admiration for the former Brazil forward [[Ronaldo (Brazilian footballer)|Ronaldo]], adding that he loved to watch footage of him on [[YouTube]]: "He was one of the first ones I looked at and thought, 'Wow. He's a goalscorer, I want to be a goalscorer.'"<ref>{{cite news |title=Harry Kane: I love to watch Brazilian Ronaldo on YouTube |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/12016/11397284/harry-kane-i-love-to-watch-brazilian-ronaldo-on-youtube |accessdate=29 August 2018 |publisher=Sky Sports}}</ref>
==Club career== ===Tottenham Hotspur=== ====Youth career==== Kane first played for a local club, Ridgeway Rovers, and joined the [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] youth academy when he was eight years old. He was released after one season for being "a bit chubby" and not "very athletic", according to [[Liam Brady]] who was then in charge of Arsenal's academy.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2018/02/12/liam-brady-arsenal-released-harry-kane-bit-chubby/ |title=Liam Brady: Arsenal released Harry Kane because he was 'a bit chubby' |first=Daniel |last=Zeqiri |date=12 February 2018 |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |accessdate=9 July 2018}}</ref> Manager [[Arsène Wenger]] stated in November 2015 that he was disappointed that Arsenal chose to release Kane.<ref>{{cite news |last=Hytner |first=David |title=Arsène Wenger: I was angry when I found out Arsenal had let Harry Kane go |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2015/nov/06/arsene-wenger-arsenal-tottenham-harry-kane |accessdate=8 November 2015 |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |date=6 November 2015}}</ref> He also had a trial at [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] but was not initially successful,<ref name=worrall>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VH2pDgAAQBAJ&pg=PT9&lpg=PT9#v=onepage |title=Harry Kane – The Biography |first=Frank |last=Worrall |isbn=9781786065384 |chapter=Chapter 1: Beginnings |publisher=John Blake Publishing Ltd |date=18 May 2017}}</ref> and he returned to his old club Ridgeway Rovers. In 2004, at the age of eleven, he joined [[Watford F.C.|Watford]] academy for a four to six-week trial, and was then given another chance at Tottenham after he impressed playing for Watford against Tottenham.<ref>{{cite news |title=Record-breaking Kane proves that Watford's loss was Tottenham's emphatic gain |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/tottenham-hotspur/12070870/Record-breaking-Kane-proves-that-Watfords-loss-was-Tottenhams-emphatic-gain.html |first=Gerry |last=Cox |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |date=27 December 2015 |accessdate=2 February 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.hertfordshiremercury.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/tottenhams-harry-kane-reveals-how-1169044 |title=Tottenham's Harry Kane reveals how Watford helped catapult him to stardom |first=Tom |last=Moore |date=5 February 2018 |newspaper=Herfordshire Mercury |accessdate=9 July 2018}}</ref> He first played at Tottenham as a [[midfielder]] – initially in a holding position, then as an attacking midfielder.<ref name=worrall/> In his early days at the club, he did not stand out as a player as he was not big nor was he particularly quick, but those who worked with him at the club noted his constant desire to improve various aspects of his game.<ref name=jim/> In the [[2008–09 Tottenham Hotspur F.C. season|2008–09 season]], he played in the under-16s side that competed in the Copa Chivas tournament in Mexico, and the Bellinzona tournament in Switzerland, scoring three goals.<ref>{{cite web |title=Unearth themselves a striking gem |url=http://www.footballfancast.com/football-blogs/harry-kane-tottenham-unearth-themselves-a-striking-gem |publisher=Footballfancast |accessdate=21 March 2015}}</ref> In July 2009, on his 16th birthday, he signed a scholarship contract with Tottenham.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VH2pDgAAQBAJ&pg=PT10&lpg=PT10#v=onepage |title=Harry Kane – The Biography |first=Frank |last=Worrall |isbn=9781786065384 |chapter=Chapter 1: Beginnings |publisher=John Blake Publishing Ltd |date=18 May 2017}}</ref>
In the [[2009–10 Tottenham Hotspur F.C. season|2009–10 season]], Kane played 22 times for Tottenham's under-18s, scoring 18 goals.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.footballfancast.com/2010/09/football-blogs/harry-kane-tottenham-unearth-themselves-a-striking-gem |title=Tottenham unearth themselves a striking gem |date=10 September 2010 |publisher=FootballFanCast.com}}</ref> Kane appeared on the first-team bench twice during the 2009–10 season.<ref>{{cite web |title=Tottenham: Results/matches: 2009/10 |url=http://www.soccerbase.com/teams/team.sd?team_id=2590&teamTabs=results&season_id=139 |website=Soccerbase |publisher=Centurycomm |accessdate=2 February 2018}}</ref> Both matches were in home domestic cup victories: one the [[EFL Cup|League Cup]] fixture against [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] on 27 October 2009<ref>{{cite news |title=Tottenham 2–0 Everton |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/league_cup/8323083.stm |accessdate=11 January 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=27 October 2009}}</ref> and the other in the [[FA Cup]] fourth-round [[replay (sports)|replay]] against [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]] on 24 February 2010.<ref>{{cite news |last=Roopanarine |first=Les |title=Tottenham 4–0 Bolton |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/fa_cup/8528819.stm |accessdate=11 January 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=24 February 2010}}</ref> He signed his first professional contract with the club in July 2010.<ref>{{cite web |title=Kane in O's loan |url=http://www.tottenhamhotspur.com/news/kane-in-os-loan-070111/ |publisher=Tottenham Hotspur F.C. |date=7 January 2011 |accessdate=31 March 2016}}</ref>
====2010–14: Loan spells across England==== On 7 January 2011, Kane moved to [[Leyton Orient F.C.|Leyton Orient]] on [[Loan (sports)|loan]] until the end of the [[2010–11 Leyton Orient F.C. season|2010–11 season]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/l/leyton_orient/9349908.stm |title=Leyton Orient sign Harry Kane & Andrew Whing |date=7 January 2011 |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> Manager [[Russell Slade]] was "happy" at his arrival and said, "I'm sure he will have an impact with us over the coming months".<ref name=Harry>{{cite web |title=From Leyton Orient to Tottenham's first team via Millwall: Charting the rise of Harry Kane |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11660/9734189/from-leyton-orient-to-tottenhams-first-team-via-millwall-charting-the-rise-of-harry-kane |publisher=Sky Sports |accessdate=18 August 2015}}</ref> He made his first-team debut for Orient on 15 January, coming on as a [[Substitute (association football)|substitute]] for [[Scott McGleish]] in the 73rd minute of a 1–1 draw away to [[Rochdale A.F.C.|Rochdale]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_2/9359393.stm#blq-nav |title=Rochdale 1–1 Leyton Orient |date=15 January 2011 |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> A week later, Kane scored his first first-team goal against [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|Sheffield Wednesday]]; making his first-ever start, "unmarked" Kane scored from a [[Dean Cox (English footballer)|Dean Cox]] freekick in the 57th minute as Orient eventually won 4–0.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_2/9362036.stm |title=Leyton Orient 4–0 Sheffield Wednesday |date=22 January 2011 |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Four-star Orient stun Owls |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/leyton-or-vs-sheff-wed/report/216323 |publisher=Sky Sports |accessdate=18 August 2015}}</ref> Slade said that he was "delighted" that Kane scored a goal on his first league start.<ref name=Harry/> On 12 February, he scored twice in a 4–1 win over [[Bristol Rovers F.C.|Bristol Rovers]], after coming on as a substitute for McGleish in the 70th minute.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_2/9387845.stm |title=Leyton Orient 4–1 Bristol Rovers |date=12 February 2011 |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> He ended the season scoring five goals in 18 matches.<ref name=Kane>{{cite news |title=Harry Kane timeline: How has the Spurs starlet gone from peripheral figure to England goalscorer? |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/harry-kane-timeline-how-spurs-5405662 |newspaper=Daily Mirror |location=London |accessdate=18 August 2015}}</ref>
On 25 August 2011, Kane made his first appearance for Tottenham, starting in the second leg of their [[UEFA Europa League]] qualification round against [[Heart of Midlothian F.C.|Hearts]], with Tottenham making changes after winning the first leg 5–0. His debut was a goalless match, although he won a [[Penalty kick (association football)|penalty]] after being fouled by goalkeeper [[Jamie MacDonald (footballer)|Jamie MacDonald]], who then saved the penalty which Kane took himself.<ref>{{cite news |last=Lyon |first=Sam |title=Tottenham 0–0 Hearts |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/europe/14569541.stm |accessdate=11 January 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=24 August 2011}}</ref> He went on to make six appearances in the Europa League [[2011–12 Tottenham Hotspur F.C. season|that season]], scoring his first Tottenham goal in the 4–0 win away to [[Shamrock Rovers F.C.|Shamrock Rovers]] on 15 December 2011.<ref>{{cite news |last=Higginson |first=Marc |title=Shamrock Rovers 0–4 Tottenham |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/16081794 |accessdate=11 January 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=15 August 2011}}</ref>
On 29 December 2011, Kane and Tottenham teammate [[Ryan Mason]] agreed to join [[EFL Championship|Championship]] club [[Millwall F.C.|Millwall]] on loan from 1 January 2012 until the end of the season.<ref>{{cite news |title=Millwall agree loans for Tottenham's Ryan Mason and Harry Kane |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/16358540 |accessdate=11 January 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=29 December 2011}}</ref> After making his debut against [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]], manager [[Kenny Jackett]] said that he had "very good debut" but was "unlucky not to score". He also said that Kane would "be a good addition" for the club in the second half of the season. He went on to score seven goals in the final 14 matches of the season.<ref name=Harry/> Kane scored nine goals in 27 matches which resulted in him being named Millwall's Young Player of the Year for [[2011–12 Millwall F.C. season|2011–12]].<ref name=YPOTY>{{cite web |first=Jay |last=Taylor |title=Millwall boss Jackett hands award to Spurs loanee Kane |url=http://www.newsatden.co.uk/2612-millwall-boss-jackett-hands-award-to-spurs-loanee-kane.html |website=News at Den |date=27 April 2012 |accessdate=16 December 2017}}</ref> His run of goals scored towards the end of the season has been credited with helping to raise Millwall in the table away from the threat of relegation that season.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2017/mar/09/harry-kane-loan-millwall-tottenham-fa-cup |title=How Harry Kane's loan saved Millwall from relegation and made him a man |first=David |last=Hytner |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |date=9 March 2017 |accessdate=19 June 2018}}</ref>
Kane spent pre-season 2012–13 season with Tottenham, scoring a [[Hat-trick#Association football|hat-trick]] in a 6–0 away win against [[Southend United F.C.|Southend United]] on 10 August 2012.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.southendunited.co.uk/news/article/100812-southend-0-tottenham-xi-6-306078.aspx |title=Southend United finished pre-season with an embarrassing 6–0 defeat to a Tottenham Hotspur XI at Roots Hall on Friday night |publisher=Southend United F.C. |date=10 August 2012 |accessdate=23 October 2014}}</ref> On 18 August, he made his [[2012–13 Premier League|Premier League]] debut, against [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/live/match/261565/report |title=Losing start for Villas-Boas |publisher=Sky Sports |date=18 August 2012 |accessdate=24 October 2014}}</ref> Coming as an 86th-minute substitute for [[Sandro (footballer, born 1989)|Sandro]], Tottenham lost the match 2–1.<ref name=Harry/>
On 31 August 2012, Kane joined Premier League team [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]] on a season-long loan,<ref>{{cite web |title=From Leyton Orient to Tottenham's first team via Millwall: Charting the rise of Harry Kane |url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11660/9734189/from-leyton-orient-to-tottenhams-first-team-via-millwall-charting-the-rise-of-harry-kane |publisher=Sky Sports |accessdate=21 March 2015}}</ref> making his debut as a substitute against [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/19528011 |last=Smallwood |first=Jimmy |title=Norwich 0–0 West Ham |publisher=BBC Sport |date=15 September 2012 |accessdate=24 October 2014}}</ref> Kane suffered an injury, breaking a [[metatarsal bone]], in the [[2012–13 Football League Cup|League Cup]] tie against [[Doncaster Rovers F.C.|Doncaster Rovers]] in only his second appearance.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/foot-fracture-for-kane-28868527.html |title=Foot fracture for Kane |newspaper=Belfast Telegraph |date=28 September 2012 |accessdate=19 June 2018}}</ref> The 19-year-old underwent his rehabilitation at Tottenham but returned to action for Norwich on 29 December 2012, coming off the bench at half time as Norwich lost 3–4 to [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.eveningnews24.co.uk/sport/norwich-city/photo-gallery-defeat-to-manchester-city-sees-norwich-city-end-2012-where-they-began-1-1756832 |title=Photo gallery: Defeat to Manchester City sees Norwich City end 2012 where they began |first=David |last=Cuffley |newspaper=Norwich Evening News |date=31 December 2012 |accessdate=2 February 2018}}</ref> However, with Tottenham having been unable to add to their attacking options during the January transfer window, they opted to recall Kane on 1 February 2013, four months before he was due to return.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/tottenham-recall-striker-harry-kane-from-norwich-8477308.html |title=Tottenham recall striker Harry Kane from Norwich |newspaper=The Independent |location=London |date=1 February 2013 |accessdate=24 October 2014}}</ref>
Twenty days after he was recalled to Tottenham, Kane joined [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] for the remainder of the season to aid in the club's push for automatic promotion from the Championship.<ref>{{cite news |title=Harry Kane: Leicester City sign Tottenham striker |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/21533301 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=12 May 2013 |date=21 February 2013}}</ref> He marked his home debut with a goal against [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]], in a 3–0 win on 26 February 2013.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2013/feb/26/leicester-city-blackburn-rovers-championship |title=Resurgent Leicester City punish lacklustre Blackburn Rovers |first=Richard |last=Rae |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |date=26 February 2013 |accessdate=19 June 2018}}</ref> He made 13 appearances for the [[East Midlands]] club, eight from the bench, and they reached [[2013 Football League play-offs#Champonship|the play-off semi-final]] before being eliminated by Watford.<ref>{{cite web |last=Sanghera |first=Mandeep |title=Watford 3–1 Leicester (agg 3 – 2) |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/22417772 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=21 March 2015}}</ref>
Kane scored his first Tottenham goal of the 2013–14 season at [[White Hart Lane]] in a [[2013–14 Football League Cup|League Cup]] tie against [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]], scoring the equaliser in extra time, the match finished 2–2.<ref name="Hull City League Cup">{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/24633791 |title=Tottenham 2–2 Hull (8–7 on pens) |publisher=BBC Sport |date=30 October 2013 |accessdate=23 October 2014}}</ref> Tottenham won 8–7 on [[Penalty shoot-out (association football)|penalties]], with Kane taking and converting the fifth of the nine sets of spot-kicks.<ref name="Hull City League Cup"/>
On 7 April 2014, Kane was given his first Premier League start for Tottenham, in a 5–1 win against [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]], and scored his first Premier League goal in the 59th minute of the match.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/26814762 |last=Chowdhury |first=Saj |title=Tottenham 5–1 Sunderland |date=7 April 2014 |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> He also scored in the following match, helping Tottenham to recover from a 3–0 deficit against [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]] before eventually drawing 3–3.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/26898645 |last=Cryer |first=Andy |title=West Bromwich Albion 3–3 Tottenham Hotspur |publisher=BBC Sport |date=12 April 2014 |accessdate=19 April 2014}}</ref> He scored for the third match in a row on 19 April, this time helping Tottenham to a 3–1 [[London derbies|London derby]] win at home over [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/26998951 |last=Sanghera |first=Mandeep |title=Tottenham Hotspur 3–1 Fulham |publisher=BBC Sport |date=19 April 2014 |accessdate=19 April 2014}}</ref>
====2014–15: PFA Young Player of the Year==== [[File:Spurs 5 Chelsea 3 (16175596592).jpg|thumb|Kane (left) playing for [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] against Chelsea in 2015. Kane scored twice in a 5–3 Spurs win.<ref name="Spurs Chelsea"/>]]
Kane made his first appearance of the [[2014–15 Tottenham Hotspur F.C. season|2014–15 season]] as a substitute against West Ham on the opening day of the [[2014–15 Premier League|Premier League season]], providing an assist for the match-winning goal by [[Eric Dier]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Rose |first=Gary |title=West Ham 0–1 Tottenham |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/28718387 |accessdate=16 August 2014 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=16 August 2014}}</ref> He scored in both match against Cypriot opposition [[AEL Limassol]] in Tottenham's [[2014–15 UEFA Europa League|UEFA Europa League play-offs]], scoring an 80th-minute winner in the first leg, and opening the scoring in the 3–0 second leg victory after missing a penalty.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/28945073 |last=Jurejko |first=Jonathan |title=Tottenham 3–0 AEL Limassol (agg 5–1) |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=23 October 2014 |date=28 August 2014}}</ref> He scored a late goal against [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]] in the [[2014–15 Football League Cup|League Cup]] to secure a 3–1 victory for Tottenham on 24 September 2014.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/29233056 |title=Tottenham Hotspur 3–1 Nottingham Forest |publisher=BBC Sport |date=24 September 2014 |accessdate=23 October 2014}}</ref> On 23 October 2014, Kane scored his first professional hat-trick for Tottenham in a 5–1 win over [[Asteras Tripoli F.C.|Asteras Tripoli]] in the group stage of the UEFA Europa League.<ref name="Asteras Tripoli">{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/29730663 |last=Canavan |first=Steve |title=Tottenham Hotspur 5–1 Asteras Tripolis |publisher=BBC Sport |date=23 October 2014 |accessdate=23 October 2014}}</ref> Kane was forced to play [[Goalkeeper (association football)|in goal]] for the final three minutes of the match, after [[Hugo Lloris]] had been sent off with no substitutions remaining, and conceded a goal when he dropped a free-kick from [[Jerónimo Barrales]].<ref name="Asteras Tripoli"/>
On 2 November 2014, Kane came on as a second-half substitute in Tottenham's 2–1 win over [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] and scored his first Premier League goal of the season to win the match in the 90th minute.<ref name=bbc.co.uk>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/30072815 |title=Hull City 1–2 Tottenham Hotspur |first=Andy |last=Cryer |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> A week later, Kane was selected in Spurs' starting line-up for the first time in the Premier League season, as the team lost 2–1 at home to [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/29868773 |title=Tottenham Hotspur 1–2 Stoke City |date=9 November 2014 |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> He retained his place in the first XI for Spurs' 2–1 win away to Hull City on 23 November, scoring the team's equalising goal.<ref name=bbc.co.uk/> Between 14 and 26 December, Kane scored in three consecutive 2–1 wins for Tottenham, against [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]],<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/30366054 |title=Swansea City 1–2 Tottenham Hotspur |date=14 December 2014 |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]]<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/30459791 |title=Tottenham Hotspur 2–1 Burley |date=20 December 2014 |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> and Leicester City<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/30544152 |title=Leicester City 1–2 Tottenham Hotspur |date=26 December 2014 |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> respectively. On 1 January 2015, Kane scored twice and won a penalty as Tottenham defeated [[Chelsea F.C.–Tottenham Hotspur F.C. rivalry|rivals]] and league leaders [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] 5–3,<ref name="Spurs Chelsea">{{cite news |last=Shemilt |first=Stephan |title=Tottenham 5–3 Chelsea |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/30600753 |accessdate=2 January 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=1 January 2015}}</ref> and he scored a further two in a 3–0 away win against West Bromwich Albion on 31 January, including one from a penalty.<ref>{{cite news |last=Oscroft |first=Tim |title=West Brom 0–3 Tottenham |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/30963472 |accessdate=31 January 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=31 January 2015}}</ref> Kane set up [[Christian Eriksen]]'s late equaliser against [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]] on 28 January 2015, a goal which put Tottenham into the [[2015 Football League Cup Final|2015 League Cup Final]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Rostance |first=Tom |title=Sheff Utd 2–2 Tottenham |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/30910040 |accessdate=2 February 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=28 January 2015}}</ref> His performances led to him being named as the [[Premier League Player of the Month]] for January 2015.<ref name=Profile/>
On 2 February 2015, Kane signed a new five-and-a-half-year contract with the club.<ref>{{cite web |title=Harry Kane signs new five-year deal with Tottenham |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/31090218 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=2 February 2015 |date=2 February 2015}}</ref> Five days later, he scored both of Tottenham's goals as they came from behind to defeat Arsenal in the [[North London derby]], his 21st and 22nd goals of the season across all competitions.<ref>{{cite news |last=Dawkes |first=Phil |title=Tottenham 2–1 Arsenal |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/31071175 |accessdate=7 February 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=7 February 2015}}</ref> After scoring against Arsenal, [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] and West Ham United, Kane was again named as the Premier League Player of the Month for February 2015,<ref name=Profile/> becoming only the fourth player to win the award in consecutive months.<ref>{{cite news |title=Tottenham: Harry Kane wins second Player of the Month award |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/31870169 |accessdate=13 March 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=13 February 2015}}</ref> Tottenham lost the League Cup Final 2–0 to rivals Chelsea on 1 March 2015,<ref name=2015LC>{{cite news |first=Phil |last=McNulty |title=Chelsea 2–0 Tottenham Hotspur |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/31572594 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=1 March 2015 |accessdate=16 December 2017}}</ref> which Kane described as the "worst feeling in the world".<ref>{{cite news |title=Harry Kane: Tottenham's League Cup defeat to Chelsea was the worst feeling in the world |url=https://www.standard.co.uk/sport/football/harry-kane-tottenhams-league-cup-defeat-to-chelsea-was-the-worst-feeling-in-the-world-10079903.html |accessdate=27 August 2015 |newspaper=London Evening Standard |date=2 March 2015}}</ref> Twenty days later, he scored his first [[List of Premier League hat-tricks|Premier League hat-trick]] in a 4–3 home win over his former loan club Leicester;<ref>{{cite news |title=Tottenham 4–3 Leicester |last=Sanghera |first=Mandeep |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/31883462 |accessdate=21 March 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=21 March 2015}}</ref> this brought him to 19 league goals in the season, making him the division's top scorer.<ref>{{cite news |last=Oliver |first=Tom |title=Harry Kane becomes the Premier League's top scorer with hat-trick for Tottenham against Leicester City |url=http://metro.co.uk/2015/03/21/harry-kane-becomes-the-premier-leagues-top-scorer-with-hat-trick-for-tottenham-against-leicester-city-5114837/ |accessdate=21 March 2015 |newspaper=Metro |location=London |date=21 March 2015}}</ref>
On 5 April, Kane [[Captain (association football)|captained]] Tottenham for the first time in a 0–0 draw with Burnley at [[Turf Moor]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2015/apr/05/burnley-tottenham-hotspur-premier-league-match-report |title=Battling Burnley blunt Tottenham's edge to deny captain Harry Kane |date=6 April 2015 |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London}}</ref> Two weeks later, he scored his 30th goal of the season in a 3–1 win against Newcastle United at [[St James' Park]], making him the first Tottenham player to reach that milestone since [[Gary Lineker]] in [[1991–92 Football League|1991–92]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/competitions/premier-league/11548208/Newcastle-1-Tottenham-3-match-report-Harry-Kane-takes-goal-tally-to-30-for-the-season.html |title=Newcastle 1 Tottenham 3, match report: Harry Kane takes goal tally to 30 for the season |date=19 April 2015 |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location=London}}</ref> Later that month, he was included as one of two forwards in the [[PFA Team of the Year]], alongside Chelsea's [[Diego Costa]].<ref name=PFA1415>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/32472834 |title=Chelsea's Eden Hazard named PFA Player of the Year |publisher=BBC Sport |date=26 April 2015 |accessdate=16 December 2017}}</ref> He was also voted the [[PFA Young Player of the Year]].<ref name=young>{{cite web |title=Tottenham striker Harry Kane named PFA Young Player of the Year |url=http://www.goal.com/en/news/9/england/2015/04/26/11172202/tottenham-striker-harry-kane-named-pfa-young-player-of-the?ICID=HP_BN_2 |publisher=Goal.com |date=26 April 2015 |accessdate=26 April 2015}}</ref> On 24 May 2015, he headed in an Eric Dier cross for the only goal of an away win over Everton on the final day of the season to confirm fifth place for Tottenham, thus qualifying them to the group stage of the following season's UEFA Europa League. It was his 21st goal of the league campaign, equalling a Premier League club record alongside Teddy Sheringham, [[Jürgen Klinsmann]] and [[Gareth Bale]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Magowan |first=Alistair |title=Everton 0–1 Tottenham |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/32770847 |accessdate=24 May 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=24 May 2015}}</ref> At the end of the season, Kane remarked that he had done more in the single campaign than he had expected to do in his whole career.<ref name=stuff/>
====2015–16: Premier League top goalscorer==== [[File:Harry Kane (24685589756).jpg|thumb|Kane captaining Spurs in 2016. He inherited the number 10 jersey at the start of the 2015–16 season]]
On Tottenham's pre-season tour of Australia, Kane attracted numerous fans while visiting the [[Westfield Sydney]] shopping centre, resulting in the club sending a minibus to escort him away.<ref name=stuff>{{cite news |last=Hytner |first=David |title=Harry Kane: I achieved so much ... stuff I wanted to do in a career, I did in a season |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2015/aug/07/harry-kane-tottenham-interview |accessdate=27 August 2015 |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |date=7 August 2015}}</ref> On 29 July 2015, Tottenham were the guests in the [[2015 MLS All-Star Game]] at [[Dick's Sporting Goods Park]] in [[Commerce City, Colorado]]. They lost 2–1 to the MLS All-Stars, with Kane scoring their consolation goal in the 37th minute after beating a challenge from [[Omar Gonzalez]], and he was later substituted in the 77th minute.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://matchcenter.mlssoccer.com/matchcenter/2015-07-29-mls-all-star-team-vs-tottenham-hotspur/recap |title=MLS All-Stars 2, Tottenham Hotspur 1: 2015 AT&T MLS All-Star Game |first=Simon |last=Borg |publisher=Major League Soccer |date=30 July 2015 |accessdate=19 June 2018}}</ref>
Kane's squad number was changed from 18 to 10, previously worn by [[Emmanuel Adebayor]]. In an interview with ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'', he said that he changed the number "to become a club legend".<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/tottenham-hotspur/11803956/Harry-Kane-I-want-to-become-a-Tottenham-legend-and-change-the-image-of-players-representing-England.html |title=Harry Kane: 'I want to become a Tottenham legend and change the image of players representing England' |last=Burt |first=Jason |date=14 August 2015 |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |accessdate=25 August 2015}}</ref> With Adebayor and [[Roberto Soldado]] having been put up for sale, he began the season as the club's only forward, and the third-choice captain behind Hugo Lloris and [[Jan Vertonghen]].<ref name=stuff/> After a 748-minute drought, he scored his first goal of the season on 26 September 2015 as Tottenham came from behind to defeat leaders Manchester City 4–1.<ref>{{cite news |last=Sanghera |first=Mandeep |title=Tottenham 4–1 Man City |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/34299624 |accessdate=26 September 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=26 September 2015}}</ref> Eight days later, he scored an [[own goal]] from [[Jonjo Shelvey]]'s corner kick away to Swansea City, but Tottenham fought back to a 2–2 draw.<ref>{{cite news |last=Dawkes |first=Phil |title=Swansea 2–2 Tottenham |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/34372499 |accessdate=4 October 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=4 October 2015}}</ref>
On 25 October 2015, Kane scored a hat-trick, including a penalty which he won himself, as Tottenham came from conceding a first-minute goal to triumph 5–1 away to [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|Bournemouth]] at [[Dean Court]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Bournemouth 1–5 Tottenham |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/34564964 |accessdate=25 October 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=25 October 2015}}</ref> Eight days later, he recorded his fifth goal of the season with the final goal in a 3–1 win at home to Aston Villa.<ref>{{cite news |title=Tottenham 3–1 Aston Villa |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/34634659 |accessdate=2 November 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=2 November 2015}}</ref> On 8 November 2015, he gave Tottenham a half-time lead against Arsenal at the [[Emirates Stadium]], albeit in a 1–1 draw;<ref>{{cite news |last=Higginson |first=Marc |title=Arsenal 1–1 Tottenham |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/34691295 |accessdate=8 November 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=8 November 2015}}</ref> this goal past [[Petr Čech]] was from his first touch of [[Danny Rose (footballer, born 1990)|Danny Rose]]'s long pass.<ref>{{cite news |last=Pierce |first=Liam Daniel |title=Harry Kane scored gorgeous one-touch goal off of an even more beautiful long ball |url=https://sports.vice.com/en_us/highlight/harry-kane-scores-gorgeous-one-touch-goal-off-of-an-even-more-beautiful-long-ball |accessdate=8 November 2015 |publisher=Vice News |date=8 November 2015}}</ref>
Eighteen days after that, he recorded his ninth goal in six matches, the only one of an away match against [[Qarabağ FK]], qualifying Tottenham to the [[2015–16 UEFA Europa League knockout phase|knockout stages]] of [[2015–16 UEFA Europa League|the season's UEFA Europa League]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Chowdhury |first=Saj |title=FK Qarabag 0–1 Tottenham |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/34896664 |accessdate=26 November 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=26 November 2015}}</ref> On 19 December 2015, Kane made his 100th appearance for the club in a 2–0 win away to [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]], and scored his 10th goal in his last 10 matches.<ref>{{cite news |last=Dawkes |first=Phil |title=Southampton 0–2 Tottenham |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/35078557 |accessdate=19 December 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=19 December 2015}}</ref> A week later, he added two more in a 3–0 win over former loan employers Norwich, putting him on 27 Premier League goals for the year 2015, breaking Sheringham's club record.<ref>{{cite news |last=Oscroft |first=Tim |title=Tottenham 3–0 Norwich |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/35139938 |accessdate=26 December 2015 |date=26 December 2015}}</ref> On 10 January 2016, he scored his 50th goal for Tottenham in a 2–2 draw against Leicester in the third round of the [[2015–16 FA Cup|FA Cup]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Tottenham 2–2 Leicester |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/35216362 |accessdate=11 January 2016 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=10 January 2016}}</ref>
Kane was Premier League Player of the Month for the third time in March 2016, after scoring five goals in four games, including one in the North London derby.<ref name=Profile /> After scoring his 22nd league goal of the season in a 1–1 draw against Liverpool at [[Anfield]] on 2 April, Kane became the club's highest goalscorer in a single Premier League season, with six games of the season remaining.<ref>{{cite news |title=Harry Kane joins elite group of Premier League goalscorers |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11675/10228695/harry-kane-joins-elite-group-of-premier-league-goalscorers |accessdate=4 April 2016 |publisher=Sky Sports |date=4 April 2016}}</ref>
Kane ended the season winning the [[Premier League Golden Boot]], finishing one goal ahead of [[Sergio Agüero]] and [[Jamie Vardy]] with 25 goals.<ref name="golden boot">{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/12028/10283818/tottenhams-harry-kane-clinches-premier-league-golden-boot |title=Tottenham's Harry Kane clinches Premier League Golden Boot |date=15 May 2016 |publisher=Sky Sports}}</ref> He was named in the PFA Team of the Year for the second consecutive season,<ref name=PFA1516>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36106596 |title=PFA awards: Leicester and Spurs dominate Premier League team |publisher=BBC Sport |date=21 April 2016 |accessdate=6 December 2017}}</ref> as he helped Tottenham to a third-place finish, and [[2016–17 UEFA Champions League|UEFA Champions League]] qualification.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2016/05/16/spurs-striker-harry-kane-positive-with-progress-despite-end-of-s/ |title=Spurs striker Harry Kane positive with progress despite end of season collapse |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |first=Luke |last=Edwards |date=19 May 2016 |accessdate=16 May 2016}}</ref>
====2016–17: League runner-up and second Golden Boot==== [[File:Manchester United v Tottenham Hotspur, December 2016 (08).JPG|thumb|Kane (centre) with his Spurs teammates before a Premier League game against [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] at [[Old Trafford]] in December 2016]]
In the absence of [[Hugo Lloris]], Kane captained Tottenham in their opening home match of the [[2016–17 Tottenham Hotspur F.C. season|2016–17 season]], assisting [[Victor Wanyama]]'s winning goal as Spurs beat [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] 1–0 in a London derby at White Hart Lane.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2016/08/21/harry-kane-shows-promising-signs-in-a-new-role-as-tottenham-edge/ |title=Harry Kane shows promising signs in a new role as Tottenham edge past Crystal Palace |date=21 August 2016 |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location=London}}</ref> He opened his scoring account in the fourth matchday of the [[2016–17 Premier League|Premier League season]], providing the final goal in a 4–0 win away to Stoke City.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/37263919 |title=Stoke City 0–4 Tottenham Hotspur |date=10 September 2016 |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref>
On 14 September 2016, Kane made his [[UEFA Champions League]] debut in Spurs' 2–1 loss to [[AS Monaco FC|Monaco]] at [[Wembley Stadium]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Flanagan |first=Chris |title=Why Harry Kane's Dortmund brace could be a genuine watershed moment |url=https://www.fourfourtwo.com/features/why-harry-kanes-dortmund-brace-could-be-a-genuine-watershed-moment |magazine=FourFourTwo |date=14 September 2017 |accessdate=6 October 2017}}</ref> Four days later, he scored the winning goal against Sunderland in the Premier League, but had to be helped off the field after twisting his right ankle attempting a tackle of [[Papy Djilobodji]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/37416108 |title=Harry Kane: Tottenham give no time frame over striker's ankle injury |publisher=BBC Sport |date=20 September 2016}}</ref> Reports indicated that the ligaments in Kane's ankle were damaged, ruling him out for six-to-eight weeks.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.espnfc.us/tottenham-hotspur/story/2954625/tottenham-striker-harry-kane-faces-two-months-out-with-ankle-injury-reports |title=Tottenham's Harry Kane faces two months out with ankle injury – reports |publisher=ESPN FC |date=19 September 2016}}</ref> After missing five league matches and three in the [[2016–17 UEFA Champions League#Group E|Champions League group phase]], Kane made his return at rivals Arsenal on 6 November, scoring from the penalty spot to equalise in a 1–1 draw.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/nov/06/arsenal-tottenham-hotspur-premier-league-match-report |title=Harry Kane spot-on to claim draw for Tottenham at Arsenal on return |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |first=Daniel |last=Taylor |date=6 November 2016}}</ref> On 22 November, he scored his first Champions League goal in the return fixture against Monaco at the [[Stade Louis II]], a game which saw Spurs eliminated from the competition with a 2–1 loss.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2016/11/22/monaco-vs-spurs-champions-league-live/ |title=Monaco 2 Tottenham 1: Spurs out of Champions League as superb Hugo Lloris let down badly by team-mates |date=22 November 2016 |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location=London}}</ref>
On 1 December 2016, Kane signed a new contract with Tottenham, keeping him at the club until 2022.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.tottenhamhotspur.com/news/new-deal-for-kane-011216/ |title=New deal for Kane |date=1 December 2016 |accessdate=1 December 2016 |publisher=Tottenham Hotspur F.C.}}</ref> On 1 January 2017, made his 100th Premier League appearance,<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2017/01/01/harry-kane-equals-thierry-henrys-goal-record-100-premier-league/ |title=Harry Kane equals Thierry Henry's goal record after 100 Premier League games |date=1 January 2017 |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location=London}}</ref> scoring the first Premier League goal of the new year against Watford on the 27-minute mark, which he extended to a brace after scoring again in the 33rd minute.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.hertfordshiremercury.co.uk/story-30023260-detail/story.html |title=Who scored the first Premier League goal of 2017? The answer is Harry Kane! |date=1 January 2017 |newspaper=Hertfordshire Mercury |location=Hertford}}{{dead link|date=February 2018}}</ref> In his first match after the birth of his daughter, Kane scored a hat-trick in a 4–0 win against West Brom on 14 January.<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/38539373"Tottenham Hotspur 4–0 West Brom"]. BBC Sport. 14 January 2017. Retrieved 14 January 2017.</ref> In the fifth round of the [[2016–17 FA Cup]] on 19 February 2017, Kane scored all three goals as Tottenham beat Fulham 3–0. This meant his fifth career hat-trick, and his second in 2017.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/38947531 |title=Fulham 0–3 Tottenham Hotspur |date=19 February 2017 |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> On 26 February 2017, Kane once again scored a hat-trick as Tottenham beat Stoke 4–0, his third hat-trick in nine games, and his second in consecutive domestic games.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/39018820 |title=Tottenham Hotspur 4–0 Stoke City |date=26 February 2017 |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> The first of these goals was his 100th in club football.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.thestandard.com.hk/section-news.php?id=180149 |title=King Kane marches on – Tottenham boss in 100-goal salute to Harry the great |date=28 February 2017 |newspaper=The Standard |location=Hong Kong}}</ref> He was named Player of the Month for the fourth time in his career in February 2017.<ref name=Profile />
In March 2017, he injured his ankle in an FA Cup match against former loan club Millwall.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/harry-kane-leaves-white-hart-10012185 |title=Harry Kane leaves White Hart Lane on crutches and in protective boot as Pochettino sweats over striker's injury |first=James |last=Whaling |newspaper=Daily Mirror |location=London |date=13 March 2017 |accessdate=19 June 2018}}</ref> On 15 April, Kane scored his 20th Premier League goal of the season against Bournemouth on his first start in a month after returning from injury. This made him the fourth player in Premier League history to achieve 20 goals in three consecutive seasons, after [[Alan Shearer]], [[Thierry Henry]] and [[Ruud van Nistelrooy]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://metro.co.uk/2017/04/15/harry-kane-becomes-just-the-fourth-player-to-score-20-goals-in-three-consecutive-seasons-after-bournemouth-strike-6576784/ |title=Harry Kane becomes just the fourth player in Premier League history to score 20+ goals in three consecutive seasons |last=Kearns |first=Sean |newspaper=Metro |location=London |date=15 April 2017 |accessdate=2 February 2018}}</ref>
On 20 April, Kane was named in the PFA Team of the Year for the third consecutive season.<ref name=PFA1617>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/39648483 |title=PFA teams of the year: Chelsea and Tottenham dominate Premier League XI |publisher=BBC Sport |date=20 April 2017 |accessdate=16 December 2017}}</ref> He was also included in the six player shortlists for the [[PFA Players' Player of the Year]] and PFA Young Player of the Year awards.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.thepfa.com/news/2017/4/13/pfa-mens-players-player-of-the-year |title=Men's PFA Players' Player of the Year 2017 |publisher=Professional Footballers' Association |date=13 April 2017 |accessdate=2 February 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.thepfa.com/news/2017/4/13/pfa-mens-young-player-of-the-year |title=Men's PFA Young Player of the Year 2017 |publisher=Professional Footballers' Association |date=13 April 2017 |accessdate=2 February 2018}}</ref> Two days later, he scored in Tottenham's 4–2 [[FA Cup semi-finals|FA Cup semi-final]] loss to rivals Chelsea at Wembley Stadium.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/39604653 |title=Chelsea 4–2 Tottenham |date=22 April 2017 |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> In the last ever match at White Hart Lane on 14 May, Harry Kane scored the 2–0 goal as Tottenham beat [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] 2–1.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/39833969 |title=Tottenham Hotspur 2–1 Manchester United |first=Caroline |last=Chapman |publisher=BBC Sport |date=14 May 2017}}</ref> With two games remaining of the season, Kane stood on 22 goals, two fewer than [[Romelu Lukaku]]. With a combined seven goals in the last two fixtures however, a 6–1 win over reigning champions Leicester City<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/39879805 |title=Leicester City 1–6 Tottenham Hotspur |first=Tom |last=Rostance |publisher=BBC Sport |date=18 May 2017}}</ref> and a 7–1 win against Hull City,<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/39912022 |title=Hull City 1–7 Tottenham Hotspur |first=Alex |last=Bysouth |publisher=BBC Sport |date=21 May 2017}}</ref> Kane finished as the top scorer of the Premier League on 29 goals, and thus won his second consecutive Golden Boot, becoming only the fifth player to do so.<ref name="golden boot 2017"/>
====2017–18: Record breaking year==== [[File:Harry Kane (35805453874).jpg|thumb|right|Kane during a pre-season game for Spurs at [[Nissan Stadium]] in Nashville, Tennessee, July 2017]] After not finding the back of the net in Tottenham's first three games, Kane scored a brace in three of his next four appearances for the club across all competitions.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/41133351 |title=Everton 0–3 Tottenham |date=9 September 2017 |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2017/sep/14/tottenham-champions-league-borussia-dortmund-harry-kane-wembley |title=Harry Kane's masterclass of craft and energy drags Tottenham to victory |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |first=Barney |last=Ronay |date=14 September 2017 |accessdate=2 February 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2017/09/23/west-ham-vs-tottenham-premier-league-live-score-updates/ |title=West Ham 2 Tottenham 3: Harry Kane wins battle of the strikers as Mauricio Pochettino declares 'I am in love with him' |first=Matt |last=Law |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |date=23 September 2017 |accessdate=2 February 2018}}</ref> His opening goal against Everton on 9 September was his 100th overall for the club, coming in his 169th appearance.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.fourfourtwo.com/us/news/kane-reaches-100-spurs-goals-12-games-fewer-henry-arsenal |title=Kane reaches 100 Spurs goals – in 12 games fewer than Henry for Arsenal |magazine=FourFourTwo |date=9 September 2017 |accessdate=2 February 2018}}</ref> On 26 September, Kane scored his first [[List of UEFA Champions League hat-tricks|UEFA Champions League hat-trick]] in a 3–0 [[2017–18 UEFA Champions League group stage|group stage]] win against Cypriot champions [[APOEL FC|APOEL]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Hytner |first=David |title=Harry Kane's slick hat-trick smooths Tottenham's path past Apoel Nicosia |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2017/sep/26/apoel-nicosia-tottenham-champions-league-match-report |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |date=26 September 2017 |accessdate=26 September 2017}}</ref> He was awarded Premier League Player of the Month for the fifth time, and named September 2017 – in which he scored 13 goals in 10 club and international games – as the best month of his career.<ref>{{cite news |last=Rosser |first=Jack |title=Harry Kane hails September as his best ever month after Premier League award |url=https://www.standard.co.uk/sport/football/harry-kane-hails-september-as-his-best-ever-month-after-premier-league-award-a3658471.html |newspaper=London Evening Standard |date=14 October 2017 |accessdate=14 October 2017}}</ref>
{{Quote box|width=25%|align=left|quoted=1|quote=I think he is in that level, with Batistuta, I would put Harry Kane in with Batistuta. Yes, yes, yes, yes – Batistuta was a killer. And very strong mentality, very strong shot, great professional, I think yes, you can compare.|source=— Pochettino compares Kane with [[Gabriel Batistuta]], September 2017.<ref>{{cite news |title=Mauricio Pochettino: Harry Kane reminds me of Gabriel Batistuta – and could be even better |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/tottenham-latest-news-harry-kane-goal-vs-everton-mauricio-pochettino-a7939421.html |accessdate=15 August 2018 |newspaper=The Independent}}</ref>}} On 23 December, Kane equalled Alan Shearer's record of 36 Premier League goals in a calendar year, having scored a hat-trick in a 0–3 away win to Burnley.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/42375899 |title=Kane scores hat-trick as Spurs win at Burnley |publisher=BBC Sport |date=23 December 2017 |accessdate=23 December 2017}}</ref> He surpassed Shearer's record the following game with another hat-trick in the 5–2 home win against Southampton, ending the year with 39 Premier League goals.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/15122/11185155/harry-kanes-record-breaking-2017-the-stats-you-need-to-know-about-the-tottenham-stars-year |title=Harry Kane's record breaking 2017: The stats you need to know about the Tottenham star's year |first=Peter |last=Smith |publisher=Sky Sports |date=26 December 2017 |accessdate=2 February 2018}}</ref> The hat-trick, his sixth of the year in the Premier League (eighth in all competitions), also made him the first player in Premier League history to score six hat-tricks in a year.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/42360004 |title=Tottenham Hotspur 5–2 Southampton |first=Caroline |last=Chapman |publisher=BBC Sport |date=26 December 2017 |accessdate=2 February 2018}}</ref> With a total of 56 goals scored in all competitions for the year, he also became Europe's top goal scorer of 2017, breaking the seven-year dominance of [[Lionel Messi]] and [[Cristiano Ronaldo]] as Europe's top goalscorer in a calendar year.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.standard.co.uk/sport/football/tottenham-harry-kane-first-player-score-more-goals-lionel-messi-cristiano-ronaldo-decade-a3727096.html |title=Tottenham's Harry Kane the first player to score more goals than Lionel Messi or Cristiano Ronaldo in nearly a decade |first=Alex |last=Young |newspaper=London Evening Standard |date=26 December 2017 |accessdate=26 December 2017}}</ref>
In January 2018, he scored twice in the 4–0 home win against Everton, and became Tottenham's top goalscorer in the Premier League era, breaking Teddy Sheringham's record of 97 Premier League goals for the club.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/jan/13/tottenham-everton-premier-league-report-harry-kane |title=Tottenham outclass uninspired Everton as Harry Kane reaches new milestone |first=Jacob |last=Steinberg |newspaper=The Observer |location=London |date=13 January 2018 |accessdate=2 February 2018}}</ref> On 4 February, Kane scored an added-time penalty to equalise in a 2–2 draw with Liverpool at [[Anfield]] for his [[List of Premier League players with 100 or more goals|100th Premier League goal]]; he achieved the century of league goals in 141 games, beaten only by [[Alan Shearer]]'s 124.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.standard.co.uk/sport/football/tottenham-star-harry-kane-to-wear-special-boots-against-arsenal-to-mark-100-premier-league-goals-a3763286.html |title=Tottenham star Harry Kane to wear special boots against Arsenal to mark 100 Premier League goals |first=Tom |last=Dutton |newspaper=London Evening Standard |date=10 February 2018 |accessdate=19 June 2018}}</ref> He was named in the PFA Team of the Year for the fourth consecutive season in April 2018, alongside fellow forwards [[Mohamed Salah]] and Sergio Agüero.<ref name=PFA1718>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/43810017 |title=Manchester City players dominate PFA team of the year |publisher=BBC Sport |date=18 April 2018 |accessdate=5 May 2018}}</ref> On 8 June, Kane signed a new contract to keep him at the club until 2024.<ref>{{cite news |title=Harry Kane: Tottenham striker signs new contract until 2024 |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/44416749 |accessdate=8 June 2018 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=8 June 2018}}</ref>
==== 2018–19 ====
Kane started the season opener against Newcastle United without scoring, before opening his account against [[Fulham FC|Fulham]] the following weekend. In doing so he ended his hoodoo of failing to score a Premier League goal in the month of August.<ref>{{cite news |title=Tottenham Fulham Match Report |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/45153221 |accessdate=18 August 2018 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=18 August 2018}}</ref> He also scored for the first time at [[Old Trafford]] in the following game as Tottenham won 3–0 in what was only their third away win against Manchester United since 1992, as well as the biggest away win against the club in 46 years.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2018/08/27/manchester-united-vs-tottenham-premier-league-live-score-latest/ |title=Lucas Moura piles misery on Jose Mourinho as Tottenham expose Manchester United's brittle defence |first=Sam |last=Wallace |date=27 August 2018 |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |accessdate=28 August 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://talksport.com/football/415729/manchester-united-tottenham-hotspur-jose-mourinho-harry-kane-lucas-moura/ |title=Manchester United 0–3 Tottenham Hotspur: Visitors end Old Trafford hoodoo in style to pile pressure on Jose Mourinho |first=Sean |last=O'Brien |date=27 August 2018 |publisher=Talksport |accessdate=28 August 2018}}</ref> He scored the opening goal against [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff]] on 1 January 2019, and with that goal, he became the first player to have scored a goal against every Premier League team he has faced.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.standard.co.uk/sport/football/tottenham/harry-kane-premier-league-goal-record-28-times-the-tottenham-striker-has-hit-the-net-a4028761.html |title= Harry Kane's Premier League goal record: The Tottenham star's best strikes from remarkable 28 team tally |first=Tony |last=Mogan |work=Evening Standard |date=2 February 2018}}</ref> On 13 January 2019, in a match against Manchester United, Kane injured his ankle ligaments late in the game, thereby missing some crucial games including the Champions League last-16 ties.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/46884787 |title=Harry Kane: Tottenham striker out until March with ankle injury |work=BBC Sport |date=15 January 2019}}</ref>
He returned to the first team squad on 23 February 2019, in a match against Burnley, and was immediately placed in the starting XI. He scored the equalizing goal in the 65th minute to tie the score 1-1, although the match ended a 1-2 defeat.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/47262464 |title=Burnley 2-1 Tottenham |work=BBC Sport |accessdate=27 February 2019}}</ref>
==International career== ===Youth=== [[File:Harry Kane.jpg|thumb|upright|Kane warming up for England at the [[2012 UEFA European Under-19 Championship]]]]
In January 2010, Kane was called up to play for the [[England national under-17 football team|England under-17 team]] for the Algarve Tournament in Portugal.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thefootballnetwork.net/main/s565/st153364.htm |title=U17 squad announced |date=23 January 2010 |publisher=Thefootballnetwork.net}}</ref> Kane missed the [[2010 UEFA European Under-17 Championship]] due to illness, with England going on to win the tournament in his absence.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2015/mar/25/harry-kane-england-inspiration |last=Hytner |first=David |title=Harry Kane is an inspiration to all the young England players coming through |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |date=25 March 2015 |accessdate=30 March 2015}}</ref> He later moved up to the [[England national under-19 football team|under-19s]] and scored twice in a 6–1 victory over [[Albania national under-19 football team|Albania]] on 8 October 2010.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.england-mad.co.uk/roll/edb2/england_u19_6_albania_u19_1_567840/index.shtml |title=England U19 6 Albania U19 1 |date=8 October 2010 |publisher=england-mad.co.uk |accessdate=15 January 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120317053936/http://www.england-mad.co.uk/roll/edb2/england_u19_6_albania_u19_1_567840/index.shtml |archivedate=17 March 2012 |deadurl=yes}}</ref> Kane played a large role in the England under-19s progression to the semi-finals of the [[2012 UEFA European Under-19 Championship]] in Estonia. Kane scored the winner against France in the final group stage match to ensure the team a safe passage through to the semi-finals.<ref>{{cite web |title=Tottenham striker Kane delighted to be in England scoring form in U19 Euros |url=http://www.tribalfootball.com/articles/tottenham-striker-kane-delighted-be-engand-scoring-form-u19-euros-3343721 |publisher=Tribal Football |accessdate=21 March 2015}}</ref> In total Kane appeared 14 times for England U19s and contributed 6 goals during that period.<ref name=FA>{{cite web |title=Harry Kane |url=http://www.thefa.com/england/all-teams/players/k/harry-kane |publisher=The Football Association |accessdate=21 March 2015}}</ref>
On 28 May 2013, he was named in manager [[Peter Taylor (footballer, born 1953)|Peter Taylor]]'s 21-man [[2013 FIFA U-20 World Cup squads#England|squad]] for the [[2013 FIFA U-20 World Cup]].<ref>[http://www.thefa.com/england/mens-u20s/News/2013/u20s-world-cup-squad-announcement-280513 "Final squad named"] The Football Association. 28 May 2013. Retrieved 17 June 2013.</ref> He made his debut on 16 June, in a 3–0 win in a warm-up match against [[Uruguay national under-20 football team|Uruguay]].<ref>[http://www.thefa.com/england/mens-u20s/News/2013/uruguay-report-160613 "Training win for Three Lions"] The Football Association. 16 June 2013. Retrieved 17 June 2013.</ref> He assisted [[Luke Williams (footballer, born 1993)|Luke Williams]]' goal in the opening group-stage match on 23 June 2013 against [[Iraq national under-20 football team|Iraq]].<ref>[http://www.thefa.com/england/mens-u20s/News/2013/iraq-updates-230613 "England v Iraq"] The Football Association. 23 June 2013. Retrieved 24 June 2013/</ref> He then scored in the following match against [[Chile national under-20 football team|Chile]], collecting a pass after work by [[Ross Barkley]] and firing in from the edge of the [[penalty area]].<ref>[http://www.thefa.com/england/mens-u20s/News/2013/engchi_matchreport "All square in Antalya"] The Football Association. 26 June 2013. Retrieved 26 June 2013.</ref> On 13 August 2013, Kane made his debut for the [[England national under-21 football team|under-21s]] against [[Scotland national under-21 football team|Scotland]].<ref name=FA/> In that match, he came on as a substitute in the 58th minute, and England won 6–0.<ref>{{cite web |title=England Under-21s beat Scotland U21s 6–0 |url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/live/match/292365/report |publisher=Sky Sports |accessdate=21 March 2015}}</ref> On 10 October, he scored a hat-trick for England under-21s against [[San Marino national under-21 football team|San Marino]] during [[2015 UEFA European Under-21 Championship qualification Group 1|2015 UEFA European Under-21 Championship qualification]].<ref name=Soccerway>{{cite web |title=H. Kane: Summary |url=https://uk.soccerway.com/players/harry-kane/158575/ |website=Soccerway |publisher=Perform Group |accessdate=1 April 2018}}</ref> He continued to score prolifically, with his brace against [[France national under-21 football team|France]] marking 13 goals in 12 matches for the under-21s.<ref name=Soccerway/>
Kane was named in the England under-21 [[2015 UEFA European Under-21 Championship squads#England|squad]] for the [[2015 UEFA European Under-21 Championship]] in the Czech Republic, despite opposition from his club manager [[Mauricio Pochettino]].<ref>{{cite news |title=England Under-21s: Harry Kane in European Championship squad |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/32807828 |accessdate=20 May 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=20 May 2015}}</ref> He played every minute of England's campaign at the tournament, which ended with them eliminated in last place in their group.<ref>{{cite news |title=Portugal begin with win against England |url=http://www.uefa.com/under21/season=2015/matches/round=2000408/match=2015368/index.html |accessdate=23 August 2015 |publisher=UEFA |date=18 June 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=England beat Sweden through late Lingard goal |url=http://www.uefa.com/under21/season=2015/matches/round=2000408/match=2015374/index.html |accessdate=23 August 2015 |publisher=UEFA |date=21 June 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Italy beat England but Sweden deny them semi spot |url=http://www.uefa.com/under21/season=2015/matches/round=2000408/match=2015378/index.html |accessdate=23 August 2015 |publisher=UEFA |date=24 June 2015}}</ref>
===Senior=== {{Quote box|width=25%|align=right|quoted=1|quote=To go out at Wembley and score is what you dream about as a kid. I've had so many good moments this year that it's hard to choose a favourite, but I think that tops them all.|source=— Kane speaking about his [[England national football team|England]] debut.<ref name=esq/>}}
Kane was also eligible for the [[Republic of Ireland national football team|Republic of Ireland]] through his father, who was born in Galway,<ref name="galway"/> but in August 2014 he ruled out switching allegiance, saying that he wanted to break into the [[England national football team|England senior team]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Blow for Martin O'Neill as Harry Kane rules out playing for the Republic of Ireland |url=https://www.independent.ie/sport/soccer/blow-for-martin-oneill-as-harry-kane-rules-out-playing-for-the-republic-of-ireland-30547200.html |newspaper=Irish Independent |location=Dublin |date=29 August 2014 |accessdate=2 February 2018}}</ref>
After a good run of form with Tottenham and being the third top goal scorer in the Premier League with 16 goals, on 19 March 2015 Kane was named by manager [[Roy Hodgson]] in the England squad to face [[Lithuania national football team|Lithuania]] in a [[UEFA Euro 2016 qualifying]] match and [[Italy national football team|Italy]] in a friendly.<ref name=ENG>{{cite news |url=http://www.thefa.com/news/england/2015/mar/england-squad-named-lithuania-italy |title=Harry Kane earns first call-up to England senior squad |publisher=The Football Association |date=19 March 2015 |accessdate=19 March 2015 |first=Jamie |last=Bradbury}}</ref> He made his international debut at Wembley Stadium, replacing [[Wayne Rooney]] in the second half against Lithuania, and scored just 80 seconds later with a header from a [[Raheem Sterling]] cross.<ref name="England 4–0 Lithuania">{{cite news |last=McNulty |first=Phil |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/31968091 |title=England 4–0 Lithuania |publisher=BBC Sport |date=27 March 2015 |accessdate=29 May 2016}}</ref> On 30 March 2015, the day before the Italy match, Hodgson announced that Kane would start alongside Rooney,<ref>{{cite news |title=Tottenham's Harry Kane to start for England against Italy |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/32028730 |accessdate=30 March 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=20 March 2015}}</ref> and he played the full 90 minutes of the 1–1 draw at [[Juventus Stadium]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Italy 1–1 England |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/32028730 |accessdate=31 March 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=31 March 2015}}</ref>
[[File:Laurent Koscielny of France marking England striker Harry Kane (22695724617).jpg|thumb|left|Kane (in white) playing for [[England national football team|England]] in 2015. He wears the number 9 jersey for the national team.]]
In his next appearance on 5 September 2015, substitute Kane scored the fifth of England's six goals in a win over [[San Marino national football team|San Marino]] which qualified them for [[UEFA Euro 2016]].<ref name="San Marino 0–6 England">{{cite news |last=McNulty |first=Phil |title=San Marino 0–6 England |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/33273427 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=5 September 2015 |accessdate=29 May 2016}}</ref> Kane scored his third England goal against [[Switzerland national football team|Switzerland]] in another qualifier three days later, which they won 2–0.<ref name="England 2–0 Switzerland">{{cite news |last=McNulty |first=Phil |title=England 2–0 Switzerland |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/34061844 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=8 September 2015 |accessdate=29 May 2016}}</ref> On 12 October 2015, as England finished their qualification campaign with a 10th win from 10 matches, Kane's shot hit the post for an [[own goal]] by Lithuanian goalkeeper [[Giedrius Arlauskis]] in a 3–0 away victory.<ref>{{cite news |title=Lithuania 0–3 England |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/33544077 |accessdate=12 October 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=12 October 2015}}</ref>
On 22 May 2016, Kane opened the scoring in a 2–1 friendly win over [[Turkey national football team|Turkey]] at the [[City of Manchester Stadium]], but later missed a penalty. He was the first England player to fail to score from the penalty spot during a game since [[Frank Lampard]] in 2010, and the first to miss the target since [[Peter Crouch]] in 2006.<ref name="England 2–1 Turkey">{{cite news |last=Chris |first=Bevan |title=England 2–1 Turkey |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36295279 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=22 May 2016 |accessdate=29 May 2016}}</ref> At the European Championship in France that June, Kane was assigned to take [[corner kick]]s, a tactic which was criticised by pundits,<ref>{{cite news |last=Smith |first=Peter |title=Why is Harry Kane on corners? England striker's new role criticised |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/12016/10311456/why-is-harry-kane-on-corners-england-strikers-new-role-criticised |accessdate=28 June 2016 |publisher=Sky Sports |date=13 June 2016}}</ref> but defended by Hodgson, who said that Kane was the best for the role.<ref>{{cite news |last=Cross |first=John |title=England boss Roy Hodgson defends using striker Harry Kane to take corner kicks 9 |url=http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/sport/football/football-match-reports/england-boss-roy-hodgson-defends-8175351#p2eQCjKSBvXAfECV.97 |accessdate=28 June 2016 |newspaper=Daily Record |location=Glasgow |date=13 June 2016}}</ref>
On 10 June 2017, Kane [[List of England national football team captains|captained England]] for the first time in their [[2018 FIFA World Cup qualification – UEFA Group F|2018 FIFA World Cup qualifier]] with [[Scotland national football team|Scotland]] at [[Hampden Park]], scoring an added-time equaliser to rescue a 2–2 draw.<ref name="Scotland 2–2 England">{{cite news |first=Phil |last=McNulty |title=Scotland 2–2 England |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40141512 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=10 June 2017 |accessdate=11 June 2017}}</ref> On 5 October, he scored an added-time winner against [[Slovenia national football team|Slovenia]] which confirmed England's qualification to the 2018 FIFA World Cup.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2017/oct/05/england-slovenia-world-cup-qualifier-match-report |title=Harry Kane late strike against Slovenia secures England's World Cup place |last=Taylor |first=Daniel |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |date=5 October 2017 |accessdate=6 October 2017}}</ref>
[[File:England vs Panama 2018.jpg|thumb|right|Kane (right) and [[John Stones]] [[Goal celebration|celebrating a goal]] against [[Panama national football team|Panama]] at the [[2018 FIFA World Cup]]]] Kane was named in the 23-man [[2018 FIFA World Cup squads#England|England squad]] for the [[2018 FIFA World Cup]] and was made captain.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/44138600 |title=England World Cup squad: Trent Alexander-Arnold in 23-man squad |publisher=BBC Sport |date=16 May 2018 |accessdate=17 May 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/12016/11381470/harry-kane-to-captain-england-at-world-cup-in-russia |title=Harry Kane to captain England at World Cup in Russia |publisher=Sky sports |date=22 May 2018 |accessdate=22 May 2018}}</ref> On 18 June, Kane scored both of England's goals in a 2–1 win over [[Tunisia national football team|Tunisia]], his winning goal coming deep in injury time, in the team's opening group game of the World Cup.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/jun/18/tunisia-england-world-cup-match-report |title=Kane double ensures England defeat Tunisia in World Cup opener |first=Daniel |last=Taylor |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |date=19 June 2018 |accessdate=19 June 2018}}</ref> In the next group game
